title: Book
text:
I am currently writing an open-source textbook based on my teaching titled Data Analysis for Journalism and Political Communication. The book is an introduction to the principles of data analysis and data communication for journalists and political professionals. Readers are also introduced to R programming language. Topics include:

Data generating process
Researcher biases
Correlation vs. causation
Data ethics
Art and science of data visualization
Sampling
Political Polling
Hypothesis Testing
Regression

Anticipated publication date is August 2025.

title: About Me
text:
I have 11 years of experience as a data analytics and product leader, using my social science background and statistical expertise to turn the messy, complex, and unstructured data that humans generate into transformative tools and insights. I am a systems thinker, entrepreneur, technologist, and evangelist for new initiatives. I have a keen eye for both processes and products that create realizable business value, and successfully led multiple teams to deliver mission-critical projects for demanding organizations. I am skilled at communicating about statistics to non-technical audiences, honed over a decade as a data science educator.
I am also part of the professional faculty at the School of Media and Public Affairs at George Washington University, where I teach courses on data analysis for journalism and political communication. My course materials are publicly available on my GitHub profile. I am very proud to have earned a perfect score for four straight semesters on student evaluations of “instructor treats students with respect.”

title: Nicholas Bell, Ph.D.
text:
Welcome to my personal website. I am a data analytics professional with more than a decade of experience leading teams and projects in many different industries and types of organizations.
I am also an adjuct professor of data science at George Washington University’s School of Media and Public Affairs.
I earned my Ph.D. in political science (quantitative focus) from the University of Pennsylvania in 2022.
I am open to new connections with data analytics professionals, industry PhDs, R enthusiasts, and anyone with a curiosity about my work. My LinkedIn profile is below.

title: Teaching
text:
Data Analysis for Journalism and Political Communication
            
                SMPA 2152 | 
                George Washington University
                An introduction to the principles and practices of data analysis for journalism and political communication. Students learn to become responsible consumers and producers of data, This class includes a special discussion of political polling.

title: Teaching
text:

            Introduction to Data Science
            
                PSCI 107 | 
                University of Pennsylvania
                An introduction to acquiring, analyzing, and visualizing data in preparation for advanced coursework and research in the social sciences. Students will learn basic principles of probability and statistics, such as hypothesis testing, simple linear regression, and experiments.
